title: Preview of Metabolism
objectives: Understand biochemical forms of energy and ATP generation
Recognize redox potential and electron flow in metabolism
Describe major metabolic strategies and phases
content:
Definition & Classification

Metabolism is the sum of all chemical reactions that maintain life, including energy production, biosynthesis, and waste elimination. It includes:

  • Anabolism: Builds complex molecules (e.g. proteins, DNA)
  • Catabolism: Breaks down molecules for energy
  • Amphibolism: Pathways like the TCA cycle that are both anabolic and catabolic

Biochemical Energy

Energy is stored in high-energy molecules and transferred via:

  • ATP: Universal energy currency; produced via oxidative/substrate-level phosphorylation and phosphocreatine system
  • Other Nucleotides: GTP, UTP, CTP contribute to biosynthesis
  • Coenzyme A: Transfers acyl groups in lipid metabolism
  • Reducing Equivalents: NADH, FADH2, NADPH act as electron carriers

Electron Flow & Redox

Electrons flow from lower to higher redox potential. Molecules with more negative redox potential donate electrons (reducing agents), while those with positive values accept them (oxidizing agents).

Metabolic Strategies

  • Activation of molecules (phosphorylation, CoA binding)
  • Enzymatic catalysis for rapid, energy-efficient reactions
  • Coupled and sequential reactions
  • Creating instability around specific C-C bonds
  • Using specialized carriers for transfer of functional groups

Phases of Catabolism

Overview of how dietary fuels are broken down through multiple phases for energy extraction and biosynthesis.
